course.subject: CORE
course.name: Academic English for University Studies
course.description: This course emphasises the development of academic literacy skills, in addition to developing students’ language proficiency.Students will learn how to find and evaluate sources for academic tasks and will further develop their abilities to be critical in reading and writing, to synthesise ideas and to develop coherent arguments. Collaboration and leadership skills will also be emphasised to further develop skills and habits for autonomous lifelong learning.
course.prerequisites: CORE 1401 OR CORE 1402 OR Level 5 in HKDSE English Language with all papers at or above level 4 OR Overall bandscore of 6.5 in IELTS with all subscores at or above 6.0 OR equivalence of the above

reviews.author: The_Pierrot
reviews.title: Self-directed study on ChatGPT 👍
reviews.comment_content:
Summary of the course:
"This course is part of HKUST's Common Core Program. This course develops and evaluates your skills in 5 Core Areas for Learning (CAfL): Three of these extend your learning from CORE1402: Written Language (WL), Spoken Language (SL) and Coherence (CO). Two more are further developed on this course: Synthesis (SY) and Multimodal Communication (MM)."

In other words, we have 2 written projects and 2 video projects, 1 of each are graded which makes up 75% of the grade. The other 25% comes from Self-Directed Learning tasks that takes up time in your week, waste of time honestly :/

I also hate the fact that they still used the noisy ass timer.
reviews.comment_teaching: My instructor, Mark Hopkins, is a pretty friendly guy; he doesn't impose stupid rules or anything. Though we kinda have to participate in the class to know what's going on for the assignments.
reviews.comment_grading: Although I didn't give a lot of effort, for some reason I was given an A- here, I was expecting a B or B+ with the efforts I did. Perhaps ChatGPT did all the work for me 😌😌 Though grading may vary by instructor so again it's gacha to how your instructor treats you which kinda sucks
reviews.comment_workload:
Every week you are expected to submit the assignment and then you might be called out in class to talk about your submission, which sucks for me.

The projects are quite annoying too, they are placed near the midterm and finals, you would need to waste your time to make a video that is 4 minutes long near the finals so relying on chatgpt is always a good idea.

I asked chatgpt to give a source for engaging in creative work stuff and it gave me this funny link
https://www.verywellmind.com/the-health-benefits-of-art-4163609

reviews.author: Roni
reviews.title: local student reflection
reviews.comment_content:
小弟寫依份review個下canvas已經close左，所以會比較簡潔。
成個course好似分成4個units，去到後期會出現self-directed learning lessons (sdl) [sdl 個人唔洗出現]，每堂之前會有1-2tasks要做，上完堂之後都有task(s)要係下堂之前做。
有library quizzes(2份)，只有1 take，大約4月底deadline。
有4個electives，只需要揀2個，1個recommend 係V1/W1 deadline前做，另一個就V2 deadline 前做。
project/essays:
1. W1 : 寫一篇350-450 summaries and critique 1 source，唔計分，會比comment，堂上會要求exchange
2. V1: group project in 3-4 people，將各自係W1用既source sub 落條片度，1:30-2:00長，一樣唔計分，會比comment，堂上會要求exchange
3. W2:寫一篇750-850 summaries and critique 2 sources，會計分，事後會show feedback & comments，計分分3個aspects (written language+coherence+synthesis)
4. V2: solo project，不限source 數目，4-6 分鐘長，事後會show feedback & comments，final submission 之後有Q&A consultation，會計分並分4個aspects (spoken language + coherence + synthesis + multimodality)
**分數分level，最高exceptional, followed by exceptional/advanced, advenced, advanced/competent, competent, competent/emerging, emerging, entering (最低)**
**Rosie claim 攞 all competent C range **
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rosie 幾好人，如果你有咩問題/唔知點做可以email 拒，拒會好detail咁復你(i.e. answers in at least several paragraph)，不過拒會有時overrun，同埋拒會希望你盡量唔好遲到，要遲就提前send email inform 拒。
如果你希望係rosie面前留低印象，小弟會建議你上堂提前5分鐘到，因爲rosie拒會提前到課室門口等既時候同學生傾計，同拒傾多幾次，拒自然記得你。
reviews.comment_grading:
小弟先交代自己背景，dse出身，英文5，所以credit transfer 1402，所以無法比較兩個course邊個更靚grade。
自己情況：
library quizzes兩份各自錯一題，sdl 全做，上堂前後既tasks全部準時做，electives 準時做+做曬。
W2: advanced/competent (written language + synthesis), advanced (coherence)
V2: exceptional/advanced (coherence + mulitimodality + synthesis) , advanced (spoken language)
grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
小弟本身唔係deadline fighter，所以做所有tasks都覺得唔趕，做W1用左3 hr，W2 6 hr ，V2 1x hr，你可以當W2 as midterm, V2 as final exam，workload 算唔算多好睇個人感覺，所以比唔到評價(p.s. 因爲試過睇workload comment 結果俾人fake左QAQ)
不過做project/essays俾我既感覺似做通識paper 2 part b question 加長版，依個就見仁見智啦:)

reviews.author: Rosh
reviews.title: Overall an easy course, if you attend the lectures and do the weekly SDLs.
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers mostly multimodality, for which you are required to work in groups as well as solo to put together videos on your chosen topic. It talks about presentations, speeches, etc.
There are also Self directed learning modules alongside, which are usually on a bi-weekly basis.
Don't forget to complete these as they are part of the total score.
The course deals with synthesis, multimodality, coherence, and so on. It is actually quite useful when it comes to learning how to engage an audience. All of the modules are posted on canvas, so they're easy to refer to and follow.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Eugene was extremely helpful and his classes were well structured. He made them interactive and interesting, and don't be afraid to ask him questions regarding the assignments. His feedback was detailed and helpful.
I think the course does depend heavily on the instructor, in my case I was lucky to have my professor.
reviews.comment_grading: As long as the work is diligently done, scoring a B+ to an A+ is relatively easy. The parameters for grading are mentioned clearly, just follow them.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is high in some ways, but it is mostly easy work. Attendance is taken during classes, and there are a lot of online modules. The professor reminds us of these during class, which is why attending them is important- it's easy to miss otherwise.

reviews.author: jmui
reviews.comment_content:
F2F lessons and SDL
The content not really about language stuff, more like those paraphrasing skills.
Most topic of lessons are surrounding 21st century technology and covid those.
reviews.comment_teaching: He separated the class into different groups every lesson for group discussions, so basically I’m talking to classmates I didn’t know every lesson. I only attended half term because it’s kinda waste of time.
reviews.comment_workload:
The essay writing and video and SDL are the only thing you need complete for this course.
F2F lesson you can not attend since it doesn’t count attendance which is so good for me haha.

reviews.author: hardplastic
reviews.comment_content:
This is an English course, where you don't learn English.

The most useful thing that I learned from this course is the use of ChatGPT (Disclamer: I did not do my assignments using it). GPT is are particularly good at providing information and explaining stuffs, so I basically use it as a search engine.

Other stuffs like citations, power search, etc. has nothing to do with "Academic English". So upon completion of this course I did not really improved my English.

The necessity of the existence of this course remains a doubt.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecturer is quite fun and energetic. It you enjor talking (in English) then you will enjoy her class. Sadly, I am not those kind of people so I skip like half of the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: I got like mostly competent or advanced for my assignments and I missed two SDL as I remenber. At last I got a B which I think is acceptable.
reviews.comment_workload: Two writings, two videos, whole bunch of SDLs, and some elective modules. In short, a fking lot.

reviews.author: HU-HT
reviews.comment_content:
Oversimplified summary:
How to do research
How to write a decent enough academic blog (Summary + critique)
How to make an interesting and educational video
How to speak better

4 electives (Choose 2 to do):
1. Presentation skills
2. Online resources for language development
3. Academic writing
4. Research skills

Some lessons are self-directed learning, meaning there is no lecture and you do the SDL assignments at your own pace.

Online Library Section

You will choose your groupmates and the project
topic you will be working on for your W1, V1, W2 and V2 at the early lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching: tbh I can't really say much about his teaching because I didn't pay much attention. However, I can say that his analysis for some of the examples are pretty helpful for me.
reviews.comment_grading:
You know E-Comm grading is definitely not great.
35% W2
40% V2
25% SDL + Electives + Online Library Session Quizzes
For SDL and electives, if you do it, you get marks no matter the quality.
For the library session quizzes, just get a pass on both quizzes and you get the mark.

My results:
W2: Advanced, Advanced, Advanced
V2: Exceptional/Advanced, Exceptional/Advanced, Advanced, Advanced
SDL: 13/13
Electives: 2/2
Online Library Section Quizzes: 2/2
Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
SDL, electives and online library session quizzes don't really need much effort to do if you don't care, but you can learn some stuff in the progress.
Just recommend you do SDL before next f2f lessons.
Also recommend you do online library session quizzes and electives as soon as possible because W2 and V2 are tiresome.
Before W2 and V2, there are unassessed W1 and V1 for practice.
In W1, you write a 400±50-word academic blog to summarize and critique one source.
In V1, you and your groupmates make a 1-2-minute video about your topic.
In W2, you write a 800±50-word academic blog to share your findings from two sources.
In V2, you make a 4-6-minute video about your topic. There will be a peer review session at the last 2 lectures, so you need to finish a draft early for constructive(?) feedback from other people.
